commentary.line: This is Sidhant Maheshwari, signing off on behalf of Sriram and my co-commentators, Akshay Maanay and Pradeep. Bye folks!

That's all we have for you from this game and the series. Cricket made a return to Pakistan after 6 years, but the possibility of other teams following Zimbabwe's suit, remains to be seen. Pakistan stay on 87 points, 1 point behind Bangladesh. The ideal situation for them to qualify for the 2017 Champions Trophy will be if India beat Bangladesh 3-0 and they win their series against Sri Lanka. If that doesn't happen, their qualification will be in jeopardy. We'll have to wait for those results to see if Pakistan can make it or not. For now, it's goodbye from here.
Azhar Ali is the Man of the Series for amassing 227 runs in the series

On the other hand, Zimbabwe showed plenty of pluck. The batsmen acquitted themselves pretty well. Elton Chigumbura made his maiden ODI hundred in the first ODI, before being punished for a slack overrate. Hamilton Masakadza was consistent while Chamu Chibhabha and Sikandar Raza showed promise of a better future. The bowlers were inconsistent, but without a guiding force, they were always going to struggle on such placid pitches.

A pity that the series has ended in the way it did. Zimbabwe looked promising after restricting Pakistan to 296/9. At 68/0 after 9 overs, they would have fancied a chase, considering that they had bolstered their batting line-up. Pakistan were sloppy with the ball, but would have loved for a full game, considering their current ODI status. All in all, it's been a profitable series for the hosts - their first at home since 2009. Azhar Ali continued his rich vein of form, Hafeez and Haris Sohail looked promising while Malik made a good comeback. There was a promising debut for Babar Azam as well. The bowlers were less impressive, but they weren't helped by the pitches.

22:58 Local Time, 17:58 GMT, 23:28 IST: Well, it was inevitable. The third ODI between Pakistan and Zimbabwe has been abandoned. Pakistan win the 3-match series by a 2-0 margin. Hang on for the post-match quotes and presentations.

22:48 Local Time, 17:48 GMT, 23:18 IST: It is still raining and we are nearing the cut-off time as well. Remember, Pakistan need to be amongst the top eight before September 30th, 2015, if they are to feature in the 2017 Champions Trophy. They have a 5-match ODI series coming up against Sri Lanka next.
22:35 Local Time, 17:35 GMT, 23:05 IST: The cut-off time for a 20-over bash is around 11:30 PM local. We are running out of time. It is still raining in Lahore.
22:09 Local Time, 17:09 GMT, 22:39 IST: The rain has gotten heavier now. Things are looking bleak at the moment.

21:52 Local Time, 16:52 GMT, 22:22 IST: Oh Dear, the rain has got pretty heavy and the players are walking off. Rain stops play once again. The square has been covered as rain lashes down on the Gaddafi stadium.
8.6   Hafeez to Sibanda, 2 runs, Hafeez gives this one more air, Sibanda goes on the back foot and works it in front of square on the on-side, the batsmen run hard and get back for the second run
It has started to rain again..

21:50 Local Time, 16:50 GMT, 22:20 IST: Right, we have got some good news. The lights are back, the dust storm is over and out and the rain has stopped. Play is all set to resume.. The new target for Zimbabwe will be 281 from 46 overs
21:45 Local Time, 16:45 GMT, 22:15 IST: This is turning from bad to worse. It has started drizzling in Lahore. The entire square has been covered.
21:35 Local Time, 16:35 GMT, 22:05 IST: Oh dear, this is frustrating. One floodlight tower has gone bust once again..
21:24 Local Time, 16:24 GMT, 21:54 IST: We have now started losing overs. If this is reduced to a 20-over match, Zimbabwe's target will be 138.
21:15 Local Time, 16:15 GMT, 21:45 IST: The lights are back at the Gadaffi stadium but the dust storm has well and truly settled down.
21:05 Local Time, 16:05 GMT, 21:35 IST: There's a dust storm as well now. Looks like we will have a significant delay.
There's a power failure at the ground. Just a couple of bulbs are flickering, we will have a delay here

Welcome back.. Can Zimbabwe chase down 297? Junaid will open the bowling for Pakistan. Two slips in place..

The spinners, Cremer, Williams and Raza did a decent job. In their 30 overs, the trio conceded 157 runs and picked up 4 wickets. The fast bowlers had a poor day in the office, they leaked runs at the start as well as the end. They will need their batsmen to play sensibly, if they have to chase this down and register a consolation win. Join us back in a few minutes for the run-chase....

Hafeez and Azhar Ali for the second time in the series added a 100+ opening stand. They started off in a positive manner and continued scoring freely. The skipper looked well set for another big score before his knock was cut short by a run-out. Hafeez accelerated after scoring his fifty, but threw it away when he was on 80. After that Pakistan lost a few quick wickets, Babar Azam and Sarfraz then stitched a crucial partnership. The former on his debut, recorded his maiden fifty. Anwar Ali hit a few lusty blows to take the total close to the 300 mark.

Babar Azam gets his maiden ODI cap and is hugged by his teammates. Similar is the case of Roy Kaia, the Zimbabwean debutant.
Masakadza: 'Looks like a belter, we need to bowl well and restrict them. Lots to play for us today. Couple of changes, Mpofu is back and Roy Kaia will make his ODI debut.'

Azhar Ali: 'We will bat first. Looks a good wicket, there was no dew in the last match, we would like to make a big score. Things are going well. Babar Azam will make his debut today. It's been amazing, the crowd, can't explain, I haven't played here before, the crowd has been exceptional.'
Pitch Report: 'Another lovely batting surface. The bounce should be even and it should come onto the batsmen. Win the toss and bat first', reckons Rameez Raja

Zimbabwe (Playing XI): Vusi Sibanda, Chamu Chibhabha, Hamilton Masakadza(c), Sean Williams, Sikandar Raza, Richmond Mutumbami(w), Charles Coventry, Graeme Cremer, Tinashe Panyangara, Roy Kaia, Chris Mpofu
Pakistan (Playing XI): Azhar Ali(c), Mohammad Hafeez, Asad Shafiq, Babar Azam, Shoaib Malik, Sarfraz Ahmed(w), Hammad Azam, Anwar Ali, Wahab Riaz, Junaid Khan, Yasir Shah

There's news coming in that Babar Azam will make his debut. Junaid Khan has also been included in the Pakistani XI. Haris Sohail and Mohammad Sami will sit this one out. For Zimbabwe, Roy Kaia makes his debut as well. Mpofu too comes back into the side and Vitori and Mupariwa miss out.
Pakistan have won the toss and have opted to bat
We'll have the toss and the teams in a short while. Stay tuned.

Zimbabwe too have problems of their own. Their batters have clicked from time to time, but they have failed to match the batting quality of their opponents. Their bowling though has been very disappointing. Barring one or two bowlers, their bowlers have failed to put up a good show. Their death bowling especially, remains a big concern for the visitors. It will be interesting to see how they go about their jobs today.

Pakistan might have comprehensively beaten their opponents in the previous two ODIs, but their bowling still remains a concern. It is their batting that has clicked throughout. If it was Shoaib Malik's ton and fifties from the rest of the batsman that helped them put up a mammoth total in the first ODI, it was Azhar Ali's century that got them home in the second ODI.

Credit must go to the Zimbabwe cricket team as well. Despite the attack, they decided to complete their tour of Pakistan. The home team already have an unassailable 2-0 lead in the series. Zimbabwe could have decided against playing the final game, but they decided to finish the tour as planned after security assurances from the PCB.

International cricket returned to Pakistan after a gap of 6 years and just when it looked like that the country is heading towards some sort of normalcy, a suicide attack was attempted outside the Gaddafi stadium during the second ODI. Even though the attack was foiled, thanks to the heroics of a cop, this incident will make it hard for the PCB to try and bring more international teams to tour Pakistan.

Preview

Despite a foiled suicide attack outside the Gadaffi stadium during the second ODI, Zimbabwe have agreed to complete the Pakistan tour by playing the last of the three-match ODI series on Sunday. Security will be further beefed up even as Pakistan, who have clinched their first series win in two years, will look to seal a 3-0 clean-sweep.

Riding on Shoaib Malik's ton in the first ODI and skipper Azhar Ali's hundred in the second game, the hosts managed to win their first two matches despite the fact that the bowlers were not up to the mark. Haris Sohail and Mohammad Hafeez were also amongst the runs with the former registering back-to-back half-centuries. Pakistan will be hoping that the batsmen can extend their good run while they will also want the bowlers to pull up their socks and come up with a disciplined performance.

The Zimbabweans fought hard in both games through fine centuries from Elton Chigumbura and Sikandar Raza, but they could not out-bat Pakistan on tracks that have been ideal for the batsmen. Both Chamu Chibhabha and Hamilton Masakadza also found form, which augers well for the batting order. Meanwhile, the visitors will be hoping for Vusi Sibanda and Sean Williams, who have struggled in the ODIs, to get going. Like their Pakistan counterparts, the Zimbabwe bowlers have also not had an easy time in the first two games and will be hoping for some respite.

Date: 31 May 2015

Venue: Gadaffi stadium, Lahore

Start time: 16:00 local

Weather: Mostly cloudy with with a high of 40 degrees

Team News:

Pakistan:

The hosts were unchanged in the second match and they are likely to stick to the same team for the third game as well. However, they did re-jig their batting order for the second match by asking Sarfraz Ahmed to open and sending Asad Shafiq at number 4. It remains to be seen if Pakistan persist with this strategy or get Mohammad Hafeez, Haris Sohail and Shoaib Malik back to their usual positions.

Probable XI: Azhar Ali (c), Mohammad Hafeez, Shoaib Malik, Haris Sohail, Asad Shafiq, Sarfraz Ahmed (wk), Hammad Azam, Anwar Ali, Wahab Riaz, Mohammad Sami, Yasir Shah

Zimbabwe:

The visitors will again be without the services of their regular skipper Chigumbura, who is serving a two-match ban for a slow over-rate offence in the first match. Masakadza, who captained in his absence, announced four changes for the previous match. Prosper Utseya (illness), Craig Ervine (injury) and Chris Mpofu were the ones who missed the second match along with Chigumbura, while Charles Coventry, Graeme Cremer, Chamu Chibhabha and Tawanda Mupariwa featured in the eleven. Among them, Chibhabha will retain his place, having scored a fine 99, while it remains to be seen if Zimbabwe bring back Utseya and Ervine.

Probable XI: Chamu Chibhabha, Vusi Sibanda, Hamilton Masakadza (c), Sean Williams, Richmond Mutumbami(wk), Sikandar Raza, Prosper Utseya, Graeme Cremer, Tawanda Mupariwa, Brian Vitori, Tinashe Panyangara

Quotes:

I wanted to mould myself according to how the game has changed. Hopefully, I can continue with this form even longer:

- Azhar Ali is eager to come up with another big knock.

We don't get to play that many games, so the guys have to rally and pull something out the hat

- Zimbabwe stand-in skipper Hamilton Masakadza hopes his team can finish off on a high.
